sn24.19:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.19:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.19:1.3.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā, esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti?
sn24.19:1.3.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

sn24.19:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.19:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.19:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.19:2.2.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.19:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.19:2.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.19:2.7.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.19:3.4.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya—
sn24.19:3.4.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn24.19:3.5.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

sn24.19:3.7.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.19:3.7.eng: “And so, when suffering exists, because of grasping suffering and insisting on suffering, the view arises:

sn24.19:3.8.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.19:3.14.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya
sn24.19:3.14.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”

sn24.19:3.17.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.19:3.17.eng: “And so, when suffering exists, because of grasping suffering and insisting on suffering, the view arises:

sn24.19:3.18.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā, esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti.
sn24.19:3.18.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”

sn24.2:1.1.comm: Most of the views mentioned in this Saṁyutta are discussed elsewhere, so I will give references for the relevant notes.

sn24.2:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.2:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.2:1.3.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn24.2:1.3.comm: This is the basic expression of the self doctrine (attavāda) as at SN 22.8:1.5.

sn24.2:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.2:1.5.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.2:1.5.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.2:1.6.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

sn24.2:1.10.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.2:1.10.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.2:1.11.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

sn24.2:2.9.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.2:2.12.pli: “Yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.2:2.12.eng: “That which is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn24.2:2.14.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.2:2.14.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.2:2.16.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.2:2.16.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn24.2:2.17.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn24.2:3.1.pli: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imesu ca ṭhānesu kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāyapissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti—
sn24.2:3.1.eng: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt regarding these six grounds, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

sn24.2:3.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn24.2:3.2.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn24.20-35:1.1.eng: (Tell these in full as in discourses 2 through 17 of the previous chapter.)

sn24.3:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.3:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.3:1.3.pli: ‘so attā, so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’”ti?
sn24.3:1.3.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”
sn24.3:1.3.comm: This is eternalism (sassatavāda), see SN 22.81:10.7, SN 12.17:5.1.

sn24.3:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.3:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.3:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.3:2.2.pli: ‘so attā, so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’ti.
sn24.3:2.2.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

sn24.3:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.3:2.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.3:2.7.pli: ‘so attā, so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’ti.
sn24.3:2.7.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

sn24.3:3.4.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.3:3.13.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.3:3.17.pli: “Yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.3:3.17.eng: “That which is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn24.3:3.19.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.3:3.19.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”

sn24.3:3.20.pli: ‘so attā, so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’”ti?

sn24.3:4.1.pli: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imesu ca ṭhānesu kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāyapissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti—
sn24.3:4.1.eng: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt regarding these six grounds, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

sn24.3:4.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn24.3:4.2.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn24.36:0.3.eng: Neither Still Exists Nor No Longer Exists

sn24.36:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.36:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.36:1.3.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
sn24.36:1.3.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’?”

sn24.36:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.36:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.36:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.36:2.2.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.
sn24.36:2.2.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’

sn24.36:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.36:2.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.36:2.7.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti.
sn24.36:2.7.eng: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’

sn24.36:3.4.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.36:3.5.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?

sn24.36:3.7.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.36:3.7.eng: “And so, when suffering exists, because of grasping suffering and insisting on suffering, the view arises:

sn24.36:3.8.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.
sn24.36:3.8.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’” …

sn24.36:3.14.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.36:3.14.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”

sn24.36:3.15.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?

sn24.36:3.17.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.36:3.17.eng: “And so, when suffering exists, because of grasping suffering and insisting on suffering, the view arises:

sn24.36:3.18.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.
sn24.36:3.18.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’”

sn24.37:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.37:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.37:1.3.eng: ‘The self is formed and is free of disease after death’?” …

sn24.37:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:

sn24.37:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:

sn24.37:3.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

sn24.37:3.3.pli: vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.37:3.6.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:

sn24.37:3.10.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:

sn24.38:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.38:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.38:1.3.eng: ‘The self is formless and healthy after death’?” …

sn24.39:0.3.eng: The Self is Formed and Formless

sn24.39:1.2.pli: “Rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā”ti …pe….
sn24.39:1.2.eng: “‘The self is formed and formless, and is healthy after death’?” …

sn24.4:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.4:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.4:1.3.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’”ti?
sn24.4:1.3.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”
sn24.4:1.3.comm: This is a saying of the annihilationists (ucchedavāda) at SN 22.55:1.3.

sn24.4:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.4:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.4:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.4:2.2.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti.
sn24.4:2.2.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’

sn24.4:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.4:2.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.4:2.7.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti.
sn24.4:2.7.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’

sn24.4:3.4.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.4:3.5.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’”ti?

sn24.4:3.12.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.4:3.13.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’”ti?

sn24.4:3.15.pli: “Yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.4:3.15.eng: “That which is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn24.4:3.17.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.4:3.17.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”

sn24.4:3.18.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’”ti?

sn24.4:4.1.pli: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imesu ca ṭhānesu kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāyapissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti—
sn24.4:4.1.eng: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt regarding these six grounds, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

sn24.4:4.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn24.4:4.2.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn24.40:0.3.eng: The Self is Neither Formed Nor Formless

sn24.40:1.1.pli: “Neva rūpī nārūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā”ti …pe….
sn24.40:1.1.eng: “‘The self is neither formed nor formless, and is healthy after death’?” …

sn24.41:1.1.eng: “‘The self is perfectly happy, and is free of disease after death’?” …

sn24.42:1.1.eng: “‘The self is exclusively suffering, and is healthy after death’?” …

sn24.43:0.3.eng: The Self Is Happy and Suffering

sn24.43:1.1.eng: “‘The self is happy and suffering, and is healthy after death’?” …

sn24.44:0.3.eng: The Self Is Neither Happy Nor Suffering

sn24.44:1.1.eng: “‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is healthy after death’?” …

sn24.44:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:

sn24.44:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:

sn24.44:3.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

sn24.44:3.3.pli: vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.44:3.6.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:

sn24.44:3.13.pli: vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.44:3.16.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:

sn24.44:6.1.pli: Rūpī attā hoti arūpī ca attā hoti,

sn24.44:6.2.pli: Rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti;

sn24.45:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.45:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.45:1.3.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti?
sn24.45:1.3.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

sn24.45:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.45:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati—
sn24.45:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.45:2.2.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.45:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.45:2.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.45:2.7.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.45:3.4.pli: vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.45:3.4.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn24.45:3.5.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

sn24.45:3.8.pli: Tasmiṃ sati, tadupādāya, evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.45:3.8.eng: When this exists, grasping at this, the view arises:

sn24.45:3.9.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti.
sn24.45:3.9.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.45:3.15.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.45:3.19.pli: Tasmiṃ sati, tadupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.45:3.19.eng: When this exists, grasping at this, the view arises:

sn24.45:3.20.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”

sn24.46-69:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in discourses 20 through 43 of the second chapter.)
